Review Title: Discover the Majestic Beauty of Aberdeen Falls
Review Text: Welcome to Aberdeen Falls, one of Sri Lanka’s most captivating waterfalls. As we approach, you'll be struck by the sight of its elegant cascade tumbling down rugged rocks amidst a lush, verdant landscape. The falls are known for their serene beauty and the mist that often envelops them, creating a magical atmosphere. It’s a perfect spot for enjoying nature’s tranquility and capturing some stunning photographs. Take your time to soak in the beauty and peace of this remarkable natural wonder.

Review Title: Aberdeen  could throw surprises. Watch out
Review Text: A fascinating falls. You go through some lovely Mountain villages to get there.Then a descent down to the falls along a foot path. Take notice of the lovely mountain Town where you begin the journey from,Ginigathena which is intact located right on top of  a mountain surrounded by other ranges. Falls is safe but be super careful at the edge of the sand bank that extends to right underneath the falls. Swim if you may on the far end away from the falls  and never below the falls..Aberdeen needs you to enjoy _ from a distance.

Beautiful waterfall, but better if you can go there in rainy season. Otherwise you can see dried water stream. Can reach upper side and down same time. But bit of climbing there when you back. There are 2 ways from both side to reach water fall. Tack care about environment if you visit. Allocate half a day if you visit

Review Title: One of the most amazing natural waterfall
Review Text: Aberdeen is one of the most beautiful waterfall in Sri Lanka. It is located in the Ginigathhena area in the Nuwara Eliya District. You can spend your vacation here freely. Go, enjoy the beauty.

Pretty easy to reach. About 20 mts from Norton Bridge. Although distance is about 4km, the narrow and sometimes broken road makes driving slow. A normal car can go without any problems though. There is a carpark just opposite the staircase on the right that goes all the way to the falls. Pretty long way but my kids of 9 and 11 made it without any fuss. Coming back is a different story! The falls had the right amount of water when we went. It was a beauty. We can walk on the shallow sand strip right near to the falls. On either side of the sand strip it looks deep. Sand seems rather solid in the middle so we and few others walked up to the falls. There was a coffee shop halfway down the stairs, owned by a foreign couple. It was pretty good and decently priced. We had refreshments there. Rarely do we get to visit a falls where the kids could enjoy right underneath. This was beautiful!

A group of fifteen visited the picturesque Aberdeen Waterfall on 26th March 2021. This waterfall, 98 metres tall, is ranked the 18th highest in Sri Lanka. The falls are at Ginigathhena on Kehelgamu Oya, a major tributary of Kelani River. After parking our vehicle in a private yard, we walked about 1200 metres on a 3 foot (0.9m) wide built-up path to reach the falls. There are between 600 to 700 steps along the way.  It was a pleasant walk amongst the tall trees and brush. The Observation platform at the end of the path provides a magnificent view of the fall.  The waters drop into a large pool where we saw some enjoying a swim.  The pool is surrounded by rocks. I noted that some visitors to the falls had left behind their waste at the observation platform.  This is unfortunate and displays their cussed nature in failing to protect such a pristine environment.  Kudos to the volunteers from the village who collected these for disposal. On our return, we sat on log-seats at our parking lot and had some soda to recover our breadth.  Clean toilet facilities available in the adjoining house (Rs 20 pp) were most welcome! At my age of 78, I did not find the descent and the return ascent easy.  However, looking back, it was well worth the effort!  Visitors to note: It would be quite slippery after rains when wet.

Review Title: Truly felt how amazing the nature is...............
Review Text: Its 3.5 hrs (115km) away from Colombo via Awissawella Kithulgala rd. Take the Sripada turn from 43rd km post after passing Kithulgala. There is another road to reach Aberdeen falls just before Ginigathhena but reaching down the waterfall is suppored to be bit hard from that end. We actually came to visit this while staying in Hatton so we came via Norton bridge. We went to the bottom of the fall by climbing down 500m. There were cement steps and journey down and up was not had as Laxapana falls. We went during the dry season and there was no leaches.  Here there is a viepoint but who ever wants to get in to the water can go further down. But swimming in the two deep areas in eitherside is bit riskey according to the villagers. There is a shollow sand stip in the middle so we got only in to that area.

It’s a 15-20 minutes long hike through the village from where the vehicles could be parked. Leeches are there but not too many. Best time to see this falls is in the morning. (Till 12pm) Can walk close to the water fall. Do not swim in the pool on the either side of the shallow corridor. Ideal for families, although the hike could be strenuous for people with heart or knee conditions. Taking frequent breaks and hiking slow will be helpful for such people. Please don’t litter during the hike. Take your leftovers back and dump them properly.

This great waterfall is definitely worth seeing. It is a long way down to the bottom and a most difficult one back to the top. You must be in a fit condition to do it. If you are a visitor. A small observation platform is constructed close the natural pool below the Aberdeen Falls, which is picturesquely framed by rock surfaces. Despite this visitors’ terrace, travellers are rarely seen at Aberdeen Falls. It’s still an off-the-beaten-path destination.

Review Title: Worth the effort for a memorable experience
Review Text: This is a really worth the effort walking down, what seem endless, steps down to the base of the falls but when you arrive you will love it. Remember to take a sturdy pair of shoes and your swimming trunks as it’s quite tricky avoiding obstacles and roots on the way down. The pool was almost empty when we went as most people stop at the viewpoint and do go down to the pool. As you reach the viewpoint you will make your way over some large rocks  that can be a little slippery so be aware . Once you’ve conquered the thousands of steps, trip hazards and slippery rocks you’ll have a wonderful time swimming under the waterfall, don’t be intimidated by its height, the waterfall just hits you like a rain shower. Be brave , get into the lake and have a blast just don’t think about the fact you have to climb all the way back up to the top !

We went here on SL Independence Day (4 Feb) and it was very busy.  Best to avoid that maybe. However it’s a lovely spot and well worth a visit. Could be tagged a challenging walk for some but a very mixed group of ages made the walk there and back so it’s all very possible.

We went with Google maps and followed the road .the trek from there was really steep but exciting Reaches after walking for about 45min It was indeed a beautiful SF pot and lovely bathing spot Have a fresh Orange juice on the way back.Pol roti with Katta sambol al as o available

I’ve went to this waterfall with couple of friends via private vehicle. Road is narrow and have to park the vehicle at the start of the foot path. Have to go down like half an kilometer to reach the waterfall. There are steps and few leeches. Once you visit to the bottom of the waterfall it’s truly amazing. Nice view and water level was high due to monsoons.
It was one if the best places i have visited. It was nice and memorable fir all of us. Clear parth available for you to go near waterfall  and have bath.
Very beautiful place to visit. It located at ginigathhena. Ideal place to bath. Cool and calm place. Fantastic place.

You should visit this hidden gem. It's difficult to reach it but worth the effort. It is 98 m high and 8 m in width. Formed from Kehelgamuwa Oya  which is a major tributary of Kelani river. From  Ginigathhena take Ambatale road. When you reach top of hill there are 2 roads to down hill. Always take the left path. Even though it's longer than the right one, it's safe.  Right path is muddy and slippery. Villagers will recommend this path but don't get fooled by them. As it's a long hike, wear comfortable shoes and take drinking water. You may encounter leeches on your way. If you are planning to swim be cautious. Safety is priority. Have a safe journey and  wonderful memories.

To reach Aberdeen Falls from the city of Ginigathena, follow the Ambatale road to the Buddha statue at the end of the road. After a bike ride, we arrived at the entry point to the Aberdeen Waterfall. There was a short hike through the jungle about 800m. It was a great experience to see the river on a hike. Great place to visit in Nuwara Eliya district, Sri Lanka.

She 's a power packed natural wonder, at 300 plus feet , serene to a fault during height of the dry season yet wild and dangerous when the rains set in. Thus ,bathing or any water related fun at the bewitching pool at the foot of the falls is definite NO. Behold from a distance . It not easy to take in the beauty from a pic ,unless taken from far above ,so a drone could be of help for any serious shutter bug. Just off Ginigathena ,the tiny ,winding road hugging the hill sides would take the traveler to the vicinity and then the hike down hill under thick foliage to the view point.

After a ride in a tuk tuk we arrived at the entry point. From there it was a short hike trough the woods. Then we saw the fall from a viewpoint. It was great to see this fall. There were no other people there exept for some locals. Went for a swim through the fall and climbed on the rocks. They are very slippery so thar took some time. It was a great experience.

Can wallk to the base of the waterfall in dry season when there not much water. Also try climbing up to the top of the waterfall by the road path. From there you can see the surrounding area which is quit beautiful.

We discovered this natural highlight on a 40 minutes walk when we stayed at the relaxing and beautiful Arsulana Eco Lodge. A local guided us to take a shortcut, refusing our rupies to thank him. nice encounter

It's an impressive 98m fall that joins Kehelgamuwa river and Maskeli river and also known as the most beautiful location of the Kehelgamuwa river. There is a 1km walk to reach the waterfall from the end point of the Ambatale road. The walk could be tiring as its uneven and steep.

Our excursion down to the waterfall and the bathing place was quite difficult but still as we reached there it was an amazing experience. We were warned by villagers not to bathe in the pool as there’s a risk of sinking in mid so we didn’t. Sat in the rocks for some time which feels like heavenly You will not regret climbing up and down in that uneasy path for about half an hour as you see the beauty of the cascade.

Aberdeen waterfall is one of the most attractive waterfalls in Sri Lanka. One can visit there as a one day trip. Here is the route from Colombo. (Colombo-Nawalapitiya-Ginigathhena- Ella uda gama) Great waterfall situated in an unfrequented place by tourists and definitely worth seeing. It is a long way down to the bottom and a most difficult one back to the top. You must be in fit condition to do it. Better to have some local with you to show you the way.

This famous cascade is located deep in the rural Ginigathhena area. The trailhead starts at a small village called Ella-Uda, Dehigastenna; some 06 km from Ginigathhena town. The road is pretty narrow but carpeted. Go until the road finishes and proceed by foot on a gravel road surrounded by thick vegetation. Upon reaching an open area with a lot of constructions work going on, turn to your left to find a staircase leading to the fall. Mind you, There are leeches of various kinds. Bathing is too dangerous and don't try to get into the quicksand in the middle of the base pool. There is another route to the fall from NortonBridge too.
really beautiful water falls their is  viewing point also its really safe place good to visit with family

In the summer of 2018 we (Dutch familie of 4, kids 13 and 18) travelled to discover the beauties of Sri Lanka. We were on a trip southwest of Kandy and we wanted to raft (sonwe did) and wanted tonswim under a waterfall (eveny only two of us did). We chose the Aberdeen falls because of the ratings and then started the quest to find the location... we saw it at the other side of the valley, but had to ask many times for directions. We had to teave our car at the end of the asphalt road (where the bus turns) and had to go continue through the jungle on a uneven path that became smaller and smaller. We saw butterflies and reptiles, but als discovered the path was full of leeches, and we were dresses in shorts with slippers... Two of us returned halfway to the car, the rest made it to the falls: what a majestic waterfall, what a noise! We changed into swimminggear just on the rocks besides the fall, because nobody was there and carefully we stepped into the water... There are warnings not to swim because of the heavy currents: that is no understatement, but proved no to be a problem for us as good swimmers. We did not swim under the falls directly, because it would cause some headaches from the water falling from that great higth.

Great waterfall situated in an unfrequented place by tourists and definitely worth seeing. It is a long way down to the bottom and a most difficult one back to the top. You must be in fit condition to do it. Better to have some local with you to show you the way.

We were visiting Adams peak and kithulgala water rafting during our holiday. On the way from colombo to kithulgala on the a7 road we saw some signage for Aberdeen falls,so checked it out. To get to the waterfall we continued via a7 towards hatton till ginigathhena city turned right just before the city. It was about 20 mins from the city. We parked our car by the road and hiked our way though a trail which leads to the water 1km or 20 min hike approximately. There are a lot of leaches on the way,so use precaution like carry salt water or repellant spray. All walking was worth it when we got to the falls.we went to the lower part. The presence of a natural pool like area was a bonus. The current was not very strong so even a person with no swimming abilities can enjoy the place. This place is a definite diamond in the rough, the only people visiting were friends of mine which was a group of five and we had the whole pool and the fall to ourselves Visit to Aberdeen falls was the highlight of our journey. Would visit again. Highly recommended

It is well worth the trip to this awesome waterfall. While it is a bit off the track both the hike and the waterfall at the end is well worth the detour. The walk to the fall after parking your car is about 15 minutes in pretty easy terrain (there are slight tough bits). The fall itself is excellent for swimming and is in a way that getting close to the fall is easily accessible even for weaker swimmers. Would highly recommend a visit as its a great experience.

it was a wonderful hiking expereince. bdw bewre of leaches and other insects. on the time period the road is under construction. if your goin on a private car, i would recomend its advisable to pay some extra and hire a tuk tuk.

We stumbled upon to this place via our private car and drove through a remote village for 2km and had to walk another 500 m in the jungle. this walk was worth it because the experience was amazing! water falls 15 feet away from you and you can stand on the stand right in front of the water falls. visit during weekday morning to have your private waterfall experience. water is so fresh and chilled and a dip would help you revitalize your body and soul. love this waterfall
